'A sea or grey,' Scott thought, standing atop one of the surviving buildings. The skyscraper tottered at a wild angle, but it was as safe as anywhere else. 'Not very.' Below, clouds of ash blew in enormous waves past heaps of slag and incinerated brick. The city appeared to have literally melted into the ground. Cars were dull grey bumps vaguely reminiscent of trilobites. The mightiest skyscrapers were in various stages of destruction, from piles of bricks to only missing a few chunks of wall. Sometimes Scott would sit in shadowed alcoves and remember his city as it used to be. These memories could last for hours, and coming back to the real world was always so much harder each time. He had a gun in his grey backpack, strapped on over grey clothes covering his ashen skin. Even his eyes seemed to have turned grey. In Scott's world, color would often lead to death. The gun, however, was not for him. It wouldn't help if she came for him, but his fellow men were another story. But he had reasons other than self-pity for being up here today. It wouldn't do to linger in the past.

The old skyscrapers almost never had good food or water in them, but scavenging for silver and other metals here had never left him without coin. This was the third building he'd been to today, and had a good store of stuff gathered up. His client had asked for a nice set of silver and some ornate candles, and Scott had managed to deliver this time. The silver didn't match and the wax in the candles had turned to dust as he'd touched it, but most people would be happy to have them. Scott figured he could head home now. A distant roar hastened his steps down the stairs. His thoughts drifted to home as he went down the dusty stairs on autopilot. A year ago it had been a decent apartments not too far from this building. Now it was a dank room off an abandoned subway station. Scott had gotten a desk and a chair as well as a bed. A small potted plant and a UV light marked him as a successful scavenger. Most days he wasn't too bitter. But when he was, he had a nice strong bottle of something he'd grabbed off an airdrop before that became suicide. When that ran out, he didn't know what he'd do. Maybe he'd finally use his gun.

The next roar was much closer, and Scott came back to reality. He rapidly descended two more floors, and remembered the staircase he was on was blocked off five floors from the lobby. Cursing silently, he found an exit door. The floor beyond was the sad corpse of some office. Faded cubicles and chairs, blackened walls, and shattered windows formed this silent tomb. Scott stepped forward slowly, making sure to keep something between himself and the windows. He didn't think Chantal was nearby, but too many had paid for that mistake for him to be so careless. And this time caution paid off. He caught the sound of flapping leathery wings just in time to throw himself flat. Many had wondered how a 200 foot dragon was so silent. Those same people usually didn't live long enough afterwards to get answers. But seconds later a huge form began to circle the building. Scott almost began to panic, but calmed himself before he did something stupid. She often checked these buildings for stray people. But he was well camoflagued, and far enough from the windows to be detectable. Nonetheless, when he heard her land on his side of the building and felt the place shake as massive claws sunk into the concrete and metal his heart almost stopped. He heard her menacing breathing, a slow and heavy sound. Almost more disturbing were the faint giggles moments later. A particularly strong gust of breath swept throug, and blew down a large portion of the cubicle walls. The one he sheltered behind blew away in a cloud of dust. Scott laid perfectly still. He was as gaunt as any of the skeletons or blackened corpses laying in the office. She would leave in a second. And just as he had predicted, she took wing a moment later. Breathing a sigh of relief, Scott waited twenty minutes before moving on to the eastern stairwell. He made it back to the lobby without further incident.

"You find anything this time?" Larry asked. Scott and Larry had worked together since the beginning, bringing necessary items down to the tunnels and communicating with those still braving the surface world.

"Yup, got what we came for. Now let's get the Hell out of here my friend," Scott said, grinning. "Where we're you when she...?"

"In the bathrooms. I don't go anywhere with windows anymore. Not since Jeff..." Jeff had been the third member of their group, and his wife Cindy the fourth. Both had been unfortunately close to a window when the dragon came gliding by. Thankfully the fires had been hot enough to kill them quickly, and she hadn't taken them with her as she did some of her prey. After this solemn moment the pair gathered up anything else they had left. "By the way, Saul got dragged off to go pay some gambling debt while manning the basement door. Locked from the inside, we'll have to go down a manhole instead."

"Dammit, why did you give him door? Why did you take him on at all? He's a lazy deadbeat. He couldn't carry a box down a hallway right," Scott fumed.

"Cousin's son, and we were as close as siblings. Don't know why they raised him that way but, there we have it. I'll talk to him when we get back," Larry replied, pulling a map from his pocket and looking it over. "We could walk over to Main Street and get back in twenty minutes. Then tomorrow we'll go out and give this guy his stuff."

"No, she could still be here. We'll go down the one right outside. One more hour walk, but I like being alive." That ended their conversation. The pair walked out into the streets after scanning in all directions for signs of Chantal. The manhole cover was ten feet from the door. Scott ran out and slid over a melted pile of Volkswagen and rolled up to it. He had always been a bit of a show off. Larry followed, striding forward confidently. In a few seconds the cover was moved. They tossed their packs down first, and grinned at each other.

"After you!" Scott said.

"No, no, please. I insist." Larry replied, all smiles. Scott stepped forward and put his foot on the first rung of the ladder down. Then a winged shadow blotted out the sun. His veins turned to ice, and he looked back up at Larry. The other man smiled weakly. "Guess this is it then. Next time, we go to Main Street."

Then the dragon landed. It was an earthshaking event, and knocked Larry to the ground. Scott stood paralyzed. As a human, Chantal had been beautiful. She still was, in a strange, scaly sort of way. She stared at the two from halfway down the block. On all fours she lumbered forward. Scales began to drop off, revealing normal skin beneath. By the time she had returned to "human" form, she stood on two legs at two hundred feet tall.

"I wondered when you two would get careless. I won't say I won't enjoy eating you two more than most others. You're just too good at what you do most times. But monologuing is the downfall of many villains," Chantal said as if Larry and Scott were old friends. "And I am most certaintly a villain." With a predatory grin befitting her carnivorous nature she grabbed Larry and showed him a row of pointy teeth before dropping him in. Scott mourned his friend as he watched her chew him to a pulp. It was not a quick thing, and Scott wished for his gun. It wouldn't kill her, but it would have done for him and Larry. "And now your turn my little friend!" Scales reformed over her skin, and the dragon chuckled as she bathed the manhole in deadly fire. Scott screamed louder than Larry as the heat washed over him.

121.content:
Chantal had made her home in the charred ruins of the city's one major mall. It was the only building large enough to fit her large form comfortably. In addition, it was also the only place that had enough extra rooms to contain the items she'd hoarded during her time as a dragoness. Apparently stories of dragon's hoards were true. As soon as she'd stopped growing and found herself covered in scales, Chantal found a sudden urge to find gold and put it in safe piles. Seeing as gold was not as prolific in her town as it had been in these stories, she had resorted to hoarding other things. There were rooms of airdrops, rooms of large caliber weapons, rooms filled with military vehicles, and her trophy room. When she had just started terrorizing the city, Chantal had been able to feast all day, and almost every night got to face another dragon hunter. Most didn't know what they were doing and died in seconds. The ones who have her a challenge got to have their weapons and skeletons stored in a hollowed out OfficeMart, forever reclining in office chair thrones. But that had stopped soon enough once people realized she was nigh on impossible to kill. Now they hid in sewers and tunnels like rats, and Chantal was lucky to find two or three a day. She was very happy today, she had finally killed two of her greatest enemies. The pair had stood in defiance of her, mocking her power by coming into her realm every day and returning to the underworld alive. And with a bit of professional respect, Chantal had to admit they were good at what they did. But her job was much easier, and she was better.

Nonetheless, Chantal's victory made today a special day. She would do something different today. Something to celebrate. She turned her head to look into the shadows behind her. And there huddled three shapes, today's retinue of slaves. She had found out early on that a dozen or so slaves helped keep her stockpiles in order. They could do things she couldn't at her size, including...

"Bring me two from the pit. Today is special my slaves, and I wish to celebrate!" The dragoness purred sweetly, smoke curling from between pointy teeth. Most times she stayed in her dragon form. She found it slightly more amusing than merely being herself at 200 feet. With bowed heads, the slaves shuffled off. They returned a few minutes later with two of the captives she had kept in the basements. On slow days she would bring one up for her amusement. Today she had three. "Have you really fallen so far as to forget how to count? This is three, I asked for two."

"You said today was special, so we thought you would enjoy-" Chantal charred him to a cinder.

"Don't think, it will never end well," she said, laying back against a wall. These three slaves had been reliable for quite a while. It was a little disappointing to have to dispose of them over something so foolish. She skewered another on a long claw, and brough him still kicking up to her mouth. She closed her mouth around her finger and pulled the wounded man off her finger with her teeth before swallowing him whole. The last one simply got the sole of her foot. She was already disgusted by the three standing in front of her. They had gotten her favorite slaves killed. She burned them to ashes to remove them from her sight. This whole city had come to make her sick. She knew what had to happen next. Already, three more slaves lurked in the shadows.

"Bring down the rest, I want everyone assembled in here right now. It is time for a meeting." Ten minutes later, her entire contingent of slaves stood before her. "From here on out, I will no longer be residing here," Chantal informed them. They took it in silence, as they took everything. At first a few had struggled and raged, but painful and public ends had made the survivors silent as tombs. It got very boring sometimes. "Seeing as you cannot fly with me, I release you from my service," the giantess concluded. A few looked at each other hopefully. But different people have different definitions of release. That afternoon Chantal feasted. As she finished the last one, who had crawled into a corner and tried to ward her off with an upraised hand, she thought she ought to have fed them better. They were a little too stringy for her taste. But now feeling content, Chantal spread her wings and flew skywards. Watching the city grow smaller beneath her still brought on a rush, even after all this time. There was nothing about her new body quite as fascinating as flying. Being able to swallow men whole, crushing cars beneath her feet, bathing crowds in fire, these were all exciting and fun. But just flying beat them all. She was incredibly agile in the air despite her size, and the mutation had further enhanced her lightning fast reflexes.

A different thrill filled her chest now though. She was moving on from the city of bones onto a new one, full to brimming with life and vitality. It would be like it was in the beginning again. She had decided on a specific type of city this time. A few minutes of flying brought her to the coast. Chantal angled downwards and folded her wings against her scaly back. Far below, her target didn't even suspect her presence. All she had to do was open her mouth. She hit the canoe like a bolt of lightning. The occupants had no idea she was there until the jaws closed around them, and by then it was too late. Chantal floated along the seabed, content to feel the insignificant struggles in her stomach.

Even at the immense depths she now swam at, Chantal was not cold. She burned with an inner heat that made her skin hot to the touch, even when she was human. And she could turn it up if she wanted. It had taken a while to discover, but now she had it down pat. For now, she was fine with just not freezing. She let her tail stretch out behind her, and folded her limbs as tightly against her body as possible. She knew there were dragons who could live in the water, so why not make the most versatile dragon possible? She moved through the seas like a sea snake. Chantal swam and swam, gills emerging on her neck to help her breathe. As soon as she had access to air they would disappear. She swam for hours before detecting the presence of humanity. One moment, the water was pure and clear. The next, it seemed slightly tinged by something foul. Chantal slowed down, and peered through the water to locate land. Altering her course slightly, she moved forward.

On shore, the city went about its usual business. Shipping came and went, people worked at their various jobs, and its streets teemed with traffic. Occasional news could still be heard of the Other City, the one claimed by a tyrannical dragon. But for the most part that was side news after so long. The dragoness had made no further moves, and was not presenting any threat to these people.

But today, something was going on out in the harbor. The waters had started steaming and bubbling, like something was making it boil. Along nearby beaches people left the water as it got too hot to be comfortable. One particular spot seemed to pop and fizz most fearsomely, and drew all the attention. The churned violently. Then, they slowed and stopped. Everything became unnaturally still.

All at once, the surface of the bay erupted. A column of water almost two hundred feet tall spurted into the air, then cascaded down. The falling waters revealed a massive titan, steam rising from her red scales. Two large wings unfolded from her back, and a tail whipped back and forth restlessly. She began to walk forward, towards the docks. Boats scrambled to get out of her way. One small dinghy just barely missed her foot, only to have her tail smash it under the waves a moment later. A large container ship stood between Chantal and the harbor wall. A scaly, clawed foot rose from the water and slammed down in the middle, sending huge containers and crew flying. The ship began to sink as the giantess walked through the wreck to clamber out onto dry land. Her tail grabbed up a fleeing sailor and crushed him, dropping the red mass onto the deck. She knocked aside a crane standing in her way, and stood still for a moment. Rivulets of water still ran down her hair, forming small streams coursing down her angellic face and onto her chest. They ran down along her perfect breasts, covered by scales, and into her cleavage. The water poured onto the ground below. Looking at the panic beneath her feet, Chantal laughed. She leaned back and roared, gouts of fire rocketing into the sky. She had found her new home.
