145.content:
Even through the haze of madness slowly engulfing her mind, Chantal remembered vaguely how she came to find herself in her current position. All around her, fires raged. Thousands were dead on the streets and even more would join them soon. Pillars of black smoke reached up, as if trying to choke out the sun itself. Chantal was broken, bleeding, and battered. Her tough scales were shattered, their lustrous red faded to a dull bronze. And now, her sister stood over her prepared to deliver the killing blow and claim dominion over all life. Sighing one final, ragged breath and breathing in the scent of charred flesh and ash, Chantal looked as far back as her tattered mind would let her.

"So Chantal, I heard you were working in the weapons department now. How will the almighty goddess choose to end the world this week? Will it be a supervirus? Shall some mutant race replace all humanity? Will some new atomic weapon send the earth off its orbit and into the sun?" Chantal's sister said tauntingly, poking fun at her sister. Chantal tolerated it, if only our of excitement.

"Oh, you have no idea. This could be the biggest development in genetics since the field began!" Chantal replied, babbling excitedly. Her sister's eyebrows raised, actually interested. Instantly trying to quell this look, she replied.

"Might the all-powerful one enlighten her sister Katrina as to what she is talking about?" she asked, flashing a smile. Chantal looked around the crowded dining hall, trying to determine whether anyone was eavesdropping.

"I'll have to show you."

Back in the terrible present, Chantal choked back a scream. That moment, if simply erased from time, would have prevented so much. The being tried to hold off the flood of memories that entered her damaged mind, but there was no stopping them.

Chantal raised a vial filled with blue liquid up in front of her sister's eyes. Katrina stared back, unsure of what exactly was being shown.

"This substance contains a special type of living machine. It enters the body by any possible means, pores, eyes, mouth, blood, and begins its work. It completely rewrites a person's DNA from the ground up. It will keep as much of the host's genetic information as possible, enough to retain a recognizable look, and then splice in the new information. If this works, the possibilities are endless!" Chantal gasped. Katrina looked amused.

"So why is this part of the military department instead of a medical department of some kind? This seems much more helpful in curing genetic diseases or irregularities than killing people."

"It's because of what the DNA in this vial will do to a person," Chantal said. Katrina signaled curiosity.

"Do go on."

"Dragons!"

Katrina's brow fell into a look of confusion. "And how does that make any sense?"

"If this enters a person's body, they will gain the ability to become a dragon! The mightiest beast in the world!" Chantal said, her excitement brining her voice to new levels.

"And I guess you just wrote genetic coding for a dragon yourself then, sister?" Katrina asked, still disbelieving. Chantal nodded yes. "Really? And the proof?"

"There-I haven't tried it yet. This is the only vial in existence. This was a prototype, supposed to be put on a sample of tissue disconnected from a body and then used to demonstrate that it works. The schematics for the machines and the DNA are all on the computers in this room." Katrina looked around the room at the mammoth computers stationed by the delicate-looking lab equipment.
"It would be too dangerous to put this information on a network, so all of these computers are isolated from the outside world. No data can leave or enter," Chantal's voice faded to a somber whisper. Katrina picked up the shift and looked concerned.

"What's the matter with you? This is Nobel prize material here!"

"They cancelled it. The project. As soon as the prototype was finished, the company ordered this be destroyed. I just wanted to show you so you wouldn't think I was crazy later." Chantal said, crestfallen. Katrina, surprised at the company forfeiting such a weapon, sprung forward.

"They are coming to destroy all this?" She asked, her voice gaining an icy edge. Chantal nodded glumly, turning away from her twin to survey the lab. Katrina eyed the vial. "And this is the only place this exists? Outside this room, there are no records of this substance?" Again, a glum nod. Chantal turned back, and then cringed back at the hardened look in her twin's eyes.
"Then we have to use it. If they won't let us use this power, we must do it on our own. Think of it, we'll become gods! We could do almost anything we wanted! This vial contains our DESTINY Chantal. To give up this chance would be to forsake the life meant for you!" Katrina hissed quietly, getting in her sister's face.

"I don't think this is a good idea, this is just a prototype and things could go wrong-"
"Then we'll fix them! We need to hurry and do this! When was the company going to destroy this stuff?"

"Now..." Chantal murmured, stunned at her sister's outburst. Just then, there was the unmistakable sound of boots on floor coming up the hallway. Into the lab entered four security guards and two lab technicians. At least one guard had been briefed on the subject matter, as when he saw Chantal holding the Gail he reached for his pistol. He pulled it out and aimed for the scientist. At the last second, Katrina slammed into her twin. The shot rang out and the vial exploded. Katrina stood in Chantal's place while Chantal lay on the floor. The blue liquid had splashed all over Katrina, coating her face. Chantal found droplets on herself, droplets rapidly being absorbed into her skin. Then to her horror, she saw a splash of red blood on her white lab coat. Quickly patting herself down she determined it wasn't her.

'But that means its-'
Looking up, Chantal saw her sister holding a gaping hole in her stomach. Katrina's eyes glazed over, and she fell to her knees. Chantal caught her limo sister before she keeled over completely, and cried out in anguish. The six men by the doorway looked equally as surprised. Chantal sobbed into her dead sister's body, feeling the tears run down her face and fall onto the body. But then the room went deathly silent. Except for one sound.

Katrina's laugh.

The woman whom had just had a hole blown through her stomach laughed. Her head rising from its slump, she let forth an unearthly expression of amusement not meant for mortal ears. Her hands quickly tore open her lab coat and shirt, both stained crimson with her blood. Beneath was a hideous wound from the .45 magnum, still oozing blood. But before all, the wound began to stitch itself closed. Muscle grew over the whole, and pale skin stretched over this layer. Minutes later, it was as if Katrina had never been shot. She looked up at her shooter with eyes of a dangerous predator and grinned.

"Thank you."

And then she ascended.
145.title: Polar opposites

1452.content:
With a sound like an underwater explosion, Katrina's skin erupted in a white flash. Chantal cried out as it seared her eyes, and she heard the other people in the room make similar noises. And above it all Katrina was still laughing. Shielding her eyes with her hand, Chantal tried to look back at her sister. Her body still radiated light, but it had died down enough to catch a glimpse of the figure within. Katrina was perfectly silhouetted, her gorgeous body reduced to its basic shadow. And to Chantal's horror, she was getting bigger. Having started out at about 5'9, she had been average-sized. But now she stood closer to seven feet. Chantal picked herself off the ground and tried to move closer.

"Katrina! What are you doing?" Chantal shouted.

"I have no idea, but it's amazing! I feel like a god!" Katrina almost moaned. She turned to face her sister, her eyes visible as two pinpoints of light inside the darker shadow. They squinted in concentration, and the light seemed to dull even more, pulling itself into her body. In a few seconds, the unnatural light was mostly gone. Her twin was now pushing at least nine feet, and her skin shone unnaturally bright. All traces of her clothing was gone, replaced by wisps of matter that resembled clouds shrouding her sensitive areas. She stepped towards Chantal, gently placing her hand on her shoulder.

"I can't thank you enough for doing this to me. I only wish you could experience this too, dear sister," Katrina said softly. "But now I suggest you get as far away from here as possible. This transformation isn't done, I've only slowed it. I'm afraid the rest will completely destroy everything here."

"We need to get you to a hospital or something, I need to fix this! Katrina, this could KILL you!" Chantal said with a tinge of desperation. Looking at the security guards and other scientists, she said "Help me get her out of here!" One of the scientists stood from behind his cover and walked forward. Katrina looked at him disdainfully, but he took no notice and reached for her arm. As soon as he seized it, bolts of lightning shot from Katrina into the unfortunate man. Incapable of moving his hand, the electricity fried him. Chantal gasped when he fell to the ground, dead. Katrina's skin glowed brighter, the light beginning to seep out of her again. The security guards drew their weapons and moved to surround her. The remaining scientist had conveniently disappeared among the equipment.

"You're a monster Katrina, let me help you!" Chantal pleaded. Katrina only smiled down at the shorter girl.

"Not yet I'm not." Whirling on the guards, she shot bolts of electricity at the security. They jerked wildly as huge amounts of electricity flowed through them, destroying their nervous system. Chantal scrabbled away in sheer terror as white light blasted the room again. Ducking down behind a table, Chantal listened as her sister assumed her new form. Crashing equipment and shattering glass made her think she was getting even larger. Thankfully, the room used to be a storage warehouse which gave her plenty of room to expand. Midway through Katrina began moaning in ecstasy as untold power filled her body. After almost five minutes, the light again went out. Peeking over the desk, Chantal saw what her sister had become.

Katrina's hair was still the pale blond it had always been. Her eyes were shards of emerald and her mouth a beautiful shade of red. Her perfectly sculpted breasts, an ample D cup, we're shrouded by dark thunderclouds that sparked with lightning. Down her perfectly toned stomach to find her womanhood covered by e same storm clouds. Her feet were planted over what had been the data terminal housing the schematics for the nano virus, and were joined to her supple hips by two perfect legs. Katrina herself admired her new form for a moment, although it hadn't changed much. Virtually the only thing that had been altered was her size. Chantal guessed from the way she had to crouch over she much be close to 200 feet tall.

"Chantal, your potion worked beautifully. I am truly perfect in every sense of the word! Now, I believe there was one more person around here somewhere..." Katrina said, an edge of mischief crawling into her voice. Trying to stand a little straighter, she bender her head on the roof. She grimaced In annoyance, but then smiled. "There you are!" An enormous arm shot out right over Chantal's hiding place and grabbed something right behind the next row of desks. The frightened shouts of the other man rang out as Katrina lifted him up to her face. In an attempt to free himself, he stabbed the giantess with a knife found inside one of the desks. The blade failed to penetrate Katrina's skin, and she squeezed him until a rib snapped and he dropped the blade. He gasped in agony and Katrina eased her grip.

"You wanna fight me then, little man? Okay. I had planned on letting you go, but I guess I'll test out the dragon part of this new body now," Katrina said. The scientist resorted to beating her clenched fist. But scales grew over it and nails elongated into claws. But then he looked up at Katrina's face and panicked.
"What, you don't like my new teeth?"
Chantal cringed as the crunching and snapping stopped, signaling the end of the team sent to destroy her research. Katrina rubbed her scaled stomach and burped. Giggling slightly, she remarked on the flavor of her meal.

"Well sister, I did warn you to get away. I fear that will get a little harder now. I won't intentionally kill you, but outside things might get a little hectic. Maybe here is the safest place to stay. In any case, I need to go alert mankind to their new goddess. Farewell!" Katrina called. Thunderous footsteps and breaking equipment signaled her departure. But Chantal was caught up in other things. She remembered her sister being shot, and how the liquid had sprayed everywhere. Even onto her. The lesser amount must have meant her transformation would take a little longer. But now it had arrived.

14521.content:
In some isolated part of the lab facility, the watchful eyes of the security cameras kept track of every development in the lab. That is, until Katrina's final evolution knocked out all the electronics in the room. Not wanting such a valuable development to escape, the company ordered all the security in the building to converge on Chantal's enormous lab, armed to the teeth. The sizable force, about 75 men suited in riot gear with assault rifles, marched into the weapons wing of the lab. On the way over, some strange shudderings and vibrations had been felt but nothing that would stop the men. Some personel had gotten word of some runaway experiment one way or another, and tried to leave the building in a hasty manner. This caused a general panic, and as a result the facility was locked down. The air of the inhabitants was edgy to say the least, as all knew something had gone horribly wrong but no one knew exactly how wrong.
The contingent arrived at the doorway to Chantal's workspace but encountered a small problem. Instead of a wooden door with a couple windows, they now confronted a solid wall of red plating. Puzzled but then annoyed, the team leader paced anxiously. His bosses wanted whatever was in this room, but this experience was a little too far out of his comfort zone. He believed in risks, but facing something this strange in the weaponry department of a science facility? That was closer to suicide.

"Has there been a problem lieutenant?" A stern voice squawked over the radio.

"Yes sir, there's something blocking the door," the man responded, staring suspiciously at the doorway.

"Then move it. You have your orders, there is a subject in that room who has stolen valuable company assets. We want them back, and as head of security it is your job to secure them. Am I clear?"

"Yes sir, but this stuff didn't budge-"

"You have a battering ram with you, use it! I am tired of your excuses and incompetence." The voice cut out, leaving the lieutenant angered and frustrated. Gesturing towards a grey-armored guard, he motioned for the ram. It was a 4-foot oblong pipe filled with a very dense, heavy material. Two men swung it repeatedly against the blockage. A strange groan was elicited, causing the two to pause for the slightest moment. At a nervous signal, the two resumed.

Chantal opened her eyes. Her first thought was of the ceiling, and how close it was to her face. Her next one had to do with a sensation of being tapped midway down her back. Groaning loudly, she began to roll over. Then she noticed her surroundings. The entire lab was spread below her, a miniature representation of everything she'd been hiding under during her sister's transformation. Chantal then realized she must have changed too, which explained her new size. This didn't shock her or turn her world upside down. She simply accepted is as a fact of life.

'I bet the nanites adapted my feelings to be more at home in this form' Chantal thought, examining her newly enlarged arms. What really shocked her was how strongly she resembled a dragon. The red scales were nothing like what her sister had demonstrated, but then she had stopped looking when she ate-

The knocking had gotten harder and slightly annoying. Chantal thought of the security cameras and bet it was backup to the other guard team. With a slight fear of death, she assumed that they would probably think the giant dragoness responsible for the deaths of their friends.

'Maybe if I looked more human...' Chantal thought. As if in response, her scales began to sink back into her skin. In moment Chantal looked human again. With a final thought to her decency, she glanced down at her once big, nor enormous chest. A liquid resembling molten lava ebbed and flowed over her breasts, seeming to cool and heat as it glowed and dimmed to different shades of orange. An identical covering existed over her other parts as well.

"Lieutenant, something's happening!" one of the men at the ram called. The LT glanced over and gasped out loud. The red scaling was sinking down and being absorbed by...pale rubber?

"The hell is that stuff?" he muttered, walking closer. As the last scale disappeared into it, he made either the worst or best decision of his life. Reaching out a gloved hand, he seized hold of it.

"Skin?" He muttered in shock. Suddenly, the wall rolled away from the door at terrific speed with his hand still latched on to it. As he rode the entity, he got a glimpse of what had been blocking the door. It was a girl of gigantic size! Easily 180 feet tall, she was as gorgeous as any other he'd seen. Though he got only a brief glimpse of black hair sewn with smoldering embers and a cute face it was seared forever in his mind. Thankfully his hand had gone limp and released the woman's back. The patch of flesh he'd been holding rolled under her while he continued flying another ten feet. Instead of being flattened under this mysterious giantess, he got to live to admire her another day.

But then he heard shouting from among his men, and realized they must have thought he was crushed. He tried to call out, but shots were fired and the giantess suddenly grew scaly again. He ducked down behind a nearby work station and tried to radio his squad.

Chantal's first glimpse of the troops was one of raised guns. By instinct, her scales returned a moment before they opened fire. Chantal also blamed her instinct for her own reaction, but knew that wasn't true. She opened her mouth, now full of razor sharp teeth perfect for ripping and tearing, and blew out as hard as she could. An endless stream of fire poured out at the guards trying to shoot her. The hallway seemed to ignite as it filled with flame. Chantal kept going until the horrendous screaming stopped. Flickering fires still burned cheerily on singed corpses and other flammable material nearby. Something vital inside her had changed. The tiny people shooting at her hadn't been people scared of this titanic monster that had suddenly appeared, they'd appeared as targets to be dealt with or prey to sustain her. And Chantal was not overly concerned. She did feel a burning inside her. A deep rage at all those smaller than her, and weaker, that made her feel this godly. Most of all, she hated her sister for speaking the truth.

They were gods.

The Lieutenant had hightailed it from the lab as fast as possible. He ran through a gaping hole in the wall out into the fresh air. The outside was cool and breezy. The sun shined brightly, and there was barely a cloud in the sky. But no birds sang in the various trees and bushes planted on the grounds. The LT didn't consider any of this, but ran as fast as he could towards the rocky hills near the edge of the lab grounds. Quickly scaling the wire fence, he looked behind to make sure he wasn't being chased. Suddenly, a geyser of fire erupted from a part of the complex. Quickly thanking any number or deities, the man saw it was about as far from him as could be. He then sprinted to the highest cave he could see and laid down. Over the next hour, he saw his workplace of three years be systematically set ablaze piece by piece. After the giantess had stood to her full height and bathed a small barracks in hellfire, the guard heard the sound behind him like a sail whipping in the breeze. A heavy thud launched him off the ground a little. Looking behind him, he saw another dragon bigger than the one now panting heavily amid her own fires. It grinned down at the little morsel now conveniently between her front claws. The Lieutenant gazed upwards frozen in horror. This was it. Her radiant white scales peeled away and drifted into the wind like delicate lotus petals, revealing a spectacularly human body beneath. She slowly lay down, pinning the man in her cleavage.

"A beautiful sight, is it not?" The giantess said. When the tiny man failed to respond, she laughed and continued "I meant my sister you fool. I should eat you for thinking of your overlord so basely." Just then, Chantal did something unexpected. She turned towards the spire in the center of the complex. Raising her hands over her head, she slammed them into the earth. The spire exploded and cracks radiated out in all directions. Magma seeped to the surface as Chantal and the facility sunk downwards.

145211.content:
Katrina suddenly perked up, eyeing the pool of seething magma her sister had suddenly created. She could still feel the tiny man squirming between her breasts, but disregarded him. Lunch would have to wait.

"Oh well my little treat, you'll have to live to satisfy me another day," she said as she lifted her form off him. He immediately sprinted for the cave's imagined saftey. Once again, she considered killing him just to prove she could but decided against it. Her sister was the more pressing issue. Regaining her dragon wings, she flew towards the magma. She circled lazily, buoyed upwards by the drafts of warm air. She could see veins of lava within the pool heat to white hot almost in the shape of another human. Katrina dearly hoped her sister wasn't being cooked alive, it would be difficult to go through life without a confidant she didn't consider a snack. But then again, she would probably have to kill her sister anyway to maintain her own dominance over the world. Instead of deciding what she wanted to happen in the lava, she just sat back and watched. Her patience paid off. After an hour of watching the roiling surface, something began to emerge from the pool. Lava obscured its specifics, but it looked to be her twin. She rose until her feet were on the surface of the lava, and then walked mechanically to the edge of the lake. Lava still ran off, singing paths of burnt overgrowth into the hillside before solidifying. The dragoness also noticed the cave in which the guard had hidden was on the opposite side of the lake. This small bit of concern for another's life irked her. Next time, she would just eat her victims.

Nothing she did elicited a response from the other giantess. Gently, Katrina pulled her sister to her feet. Her skin was hot to the touch. Pouring the victims in, she murmured more assurances of their power. She gently worked her jaws as the cries from inside died down. Chantal had almost reached the ship by the time it noticed her. She was under the cannon's angle of depression, and easily managed to land heavily on the outer hull. One of the automated defense turrets looked up at her, spinning up. She smashed the weapon, easily tearing the barrels out. She began to pound on the hull trying to find a weak point. Everything seemed too solid even for her immense strength. She breathed fire as hot as possible, and the hull began to heat to an angry red. But before lasting harm could be done, her breath sputtered and died. Looking around, she saw how thin the atmosphere was getting. Her pilot cargo had an oxygen tank, but she was far too exposed. A being her size needed lots of oxygen too. With a final blow, her vision going dark, she leapt off into the air. When she could take in enough air to stay conscious, she headed off in the direction the damaged planes had flown. She picked up another of the pilots, this one ejected after the plane had given out from damage. Ten minutes later she set foot on the ship's deck

1512.content:
"All craft are ordered to begin their attack! The invasion of Earth begins now!"

Millions of circular craft spilled into the atmosphere above the planet. Like a glorious meteor shower, they rained down over every major city. The crew of the ISS watched their graceful flight through space. Even the best human ships couldn't match a third of these aliens' capabilities. Even though they were slower in the atmosphere, their armor and weapons more than compensated for their bulkiness. When they began to reach rooftop height and hover, guns descended and fired randomly at the streets below. France surrendered instantly as the Eiffel Tower was destroyed by a stray cannon shot. Raptors streaked through skies above Washington D.C., Chicago, and New York to defend the civilians in the streets below. A few saucers were badly damaged before the defenders were struck down. Clumsily, they set down in parks and wide streets. They sat there, steaming, like brooding predators. As their still-flying counterparts ravaged the world, they silently prepared for the next step. After local police had been eliminated or isolated, the few grounded craft opened massive ramps. Legions of soldiers marched out of the craft in perfect lockstep, wielding deadly, futuristic-looking weapons and clad in armor as black as the void they descended from.
1512.title: The sky is falling!

154.content:
Somewhere out in the seas roamed the greatest aircraft carrier built so far. Nuclear powered and fully submersible, it could hide in the depths of the seas for months and emerge anywhere to rain destruction. Its contingent of planes ranged from strategic nuclear bombers to a large number of drones. Occasionally, it even added a dragon to its contingent of flying vehicles. And today was one such day. Chantal flew over the sunken carrier's location a few times, awaiting the vessel's surfacing. Minutes later a huge shadow rocketed up from the depths. Gallons of water cascaded off the decks, and Chantal gently glided in for a landing. The water hissed and steamed where ever she stepped as the huge amounts of heat radiating from her body evaporated the water.

From the conning tower a group of three men in dark suits emerged. They walked over to the dragoness's feet, seeming little more than insects next to Chantal. They shouted some form of orders up at her face, struggling to be heard over the whine of the ship's pumps ridding it of water. Thankfully, a small communication device implanted in Chantal's ear allowed her to hear the commander's orders.

"A small group of well-armed militiamen have seized control of some towns in (Insert Middleeastern or African nation here). As usual, go in and clear the towns of hostiles. Preferrably, we'd like a few to talk to this time." The man ordered, his imperious town coming in tinny and hollow through the receiver.

"Any civilians in the area? if so, to what extent should casualties be prevented?" Chantal replied. She did not make a habit of killing civilians, but when there were crowds of them in the way and you were a 200 foot tall fire-breathing giantess, some inevitably got crushed.

"All except the soldiers accompanying you are to be considered enemy combatants. We've given you the locations of the insurrections, any more questions can be answered on the way." Having no more questions, Chantal spread her wings and returned to the air. Quietly, the ship slipped beneath the waves.
154.title: Home 1

1541.content:
The small, sandblasted village appeared to all who viewed it, deserted. It existed around a small well, surrounded on all sides by a desert trying its best to grind the patch of life from existence. All the buildings, from squat, one-story hovels to a large 4-story hotel were the same shade of dusty tan. The cars were old and rusty, and the only ones currently in motion were the dozen or so pick-ups with machine guns hastily welded to the bed. These were the only outward signs of life easily visible. To one equipped with advanced surveillance techniques, they would see well-camoflagued sharpshooters, a few cars suspiciously weighted down, civilians whose robes concealed more than their decency, and more than the standard amount of people inhabiting the dwellings. Pvt. Jenkins was equipped with these surveillance techniques.

He lay under a camo-mat next to a tiny bush. Slowly panning his binoculars across the horizon, careful not to let sunlight reflect off the lens, he took in all the defenses the militants had thrown together. He was impressed. For a group of farmers to so rapidly assemble a formidable arsenal such as this took skill. Their weapons, while not top of the line, we're certainly comparable to even his own assault rifle. The explosive-laden cars would make most tankers think twice about charging in head-on. Those few who didn't would find themselves without a tank in short order. Stealthily, he slipped off the ridge and back to camp. It was a small group of tents sheltering a mechanized regiment charged with restoring order to the area. Making his report to the colonel, Jenkins described everything he had seen and his assessment of the town.

"Don't worry son, by night we'll have this thing under wraps and we can go home. Just talked to command, and we're getting the works on this one. Some kinda heavy unit. Should be here any second," The Colonel said, his drawl indicating heritage from somewhere in the Southern U.S. Suddenly, the group was startled by a loud thud and a small tremor that shook the frail tent. A gust of wind sent the tent flaps fluttering, and voices outside picked up.

"The Hell?" The Colonel said questioningly. Grabbing his sidearm, he stepped outside. He almost destroyed his pants, but then realized his mistake. Laughing uproariously, he strode towards the giant dragoness perched among his tanks, making them look like toys next to her colossal form. He noticed a number of soldiers rushing forwards, weapons raised against the new threat.

"Don't worry boys, I think it's on our side!" he called. Addressing Chantal, he said "You are, right?"

"First off, 'It' prefers to be referred to by 'she', 'Chantal', or wordless screaming. And if I wasn't, you'd know," the drain replied. "But anyways, I'm here to solve your problems with the insubordinate villagers. I'm taking the closest one first. Wait an hour, then start heading over. Don't try and come in while I'm still busy, it will end unfortunately for all involved. Well, excepting me."

With that, Chantal spread her wings and lifted off, sending storms of dust flying everywhere. The Colonel put his hands on his hips, muttering after her "I'll be damned".

The target below Chantal was pitiful. Why she'd been called in was beyond her. Regardless, it was a day our. Orbiting at several hundred feet, the giant woman assessed the threats and decided on her plan of attack. As usual, nothing that overly concerned her. So she went for the brute force approach. Three enemy technicals were on patrol together through the center of town. Folding her wings back, Chantal dove towards them with terrifying speed. The air blowing past her scaly face and the adrenalin rising in her blood got her as excited as always just before she started her work. The enemies barely saw what hit them. One caught a glimpse of the growing shadow and started to raise his gun, but an enormous clawed foot came down one his truck. Chantal almost left a crater as she evicerated the two outer vehicles with her feet. The middle one found itself grasped in her powerful talons. Chantal eyed the gunner, clinging for life onto his weapon, and bit down. The gunner, his gun, and part of the truck found themselves inside the dragoness's mouth. They were quickly reduced to smaller, swalloable mixtures as her vicious teeth set to work. The driver tried exiting, only to fall about fifty feet and die. Chantal roared, sending ice through the blood of every soldiers and militaman present. So they attacked.

Bullets pinged off Chantal's scaly hide. This always made her laugh, as it almost never worked. Another technical roared around the corner a block away from her. It's gunner fired wildly, thrown off by the sheer size of his target. In response, the giantess blew forth a jet of fire. It washed over the truck, burning flesh, paint and metal. In moments, the vehicle was a heap of slag. Chantal then slowly washed her fire over the nearby building. The brick blackened and cracked under the heat, and nothing alive inside had a chance to survive. When the building was baked to a cinder and the gunfire hadn't slackened, the dragoness realized it hadn't been staffed with troops doing their hardest to try and kill her. Signing it off as collateral damage, she carried on.
1541.title: Collateral Damage

choices: Burn the rest of the town down
15413.content:
Chantal stood to her full height, dwarfing most of the buildings around her. The enemy forces were forced to shoot harmlessly at her legs or thighs. One or two towers came almost up to her chest, and the intrepid sharpshooters there tried shooting at the giantess's eyes. When one nearly hit his mark, Chantal tired of them. She walked the few blocks over to the tower, crushing a cluster of sheet-metal huts on the way. Correctly assuming it was too late to run, the sniper kept shooting at the oncoming giantess. Chantal laughed at his bravery. When she was right on top of the tower she parted her enormous breasts, enveloping the tower. Then she allowed them to come crashing back together, raining shattered masonry on the streets below.

An RPG arced out from the roof of a building at her feet. It missed by a mile, but Chantal had to discourage such bravery when she could. She tried to grab the shooter in her jaws, but he dove through a door on the roof too quickly. Instead, the dragoness placed her mouth over the entrance and blew fire down the staircase. The windows exploded outward as gouts of flame poured from every opening in the building. The titaness kept flaming the building until the superheated stone cracked and melted and the screaming died down. Finding this method effective, Chantal repeated this process on several other buildings. When the soldiers discovered they were too vulnerable inside, the began pouring outside in huge amounts. She could hardly believe this many men were crammed into such a small town. However, none of them had yet to run. Chantal sighed in frustration. Instead of causing a panic and then killing the bad guys as they ran, she'd probably have to level the entire town. Almost a quarter was already in flames. But if she had to focus on one block at a time, some of her targets might escape. Her superiors might tolerate the needless slaughter of civilians, but not the continued survival of one enemy. So the enormous being spread her wings and took to the skies. Chantal circled the town, setting the entire outskirts on fire. Already a group had started to run for the hills and escaped her ring of fire. Keeping an eye on them, Chantal finished her job and then lazily glided over to them.

The refugees were climbing a small hill when a shadow fell over them. Moments later, a shockwave knocked them down as the giant dragon tormenting their village knocked them over. A scaly arm shot out, snatching up several terrified people. They quickly disappeared down the giant being's mouth accompanied by screams and horrifying crunching sounds. A scaly foot landed on another clump of unfortunate refugees, crushing them into the sand or sharp talons slicing the rest to ribbons. The last handful were roasted alive by the giantess's fire breath. Laughing,Chantal took off again. Maybe is wouldn't be so bad.
15413.title: Miscellaneous murder

choices: Chantel sticks around and chats with the soldiers.
No, stick to the job. To the next town!
154132.content:
Chantel looked back at the town for a moment--it was still surrounded by her wall of entrapping fire--before shrugging. The higher-ups did want prisoners this time, but there was more than one town on her hit list. She could wipe out at least one of them without getting chewed out. And in any case, she had an audience! And to give them a show like this, with no big finale? It was just criminal! Smirking hugely, a few stray drops of blood falling from her fangs, she made her way back into the burning town...making sure to swing her hips with every step, to give the soldiers watching a good show.

Chantel walked through her own ring of fire, flaring out her wings just as she entered the town. "Might as well go for dramatic effect," Chantel mused. With a sweep of her tail, she demolished an entire block of tin-sheet houses, creating a flying wall of debris that cut through a pick-up truck that had somehow gone unnoticed in her intitial rampage. The vehicle was cut clean in half, sending the cabin flying away from the bed and the unfortunate rear gunner sprawling in the sand. The man feebly tried to drag himself away, only to be crushed into a red paste under a scaly foot as Chantel strode over to the other half of the truck, still swinging her hips.

"Oh, that's not good," the dragoness taunted as she bent over to snatch up the truck's cabin in her claws, trapping the driver inside. "I don't think your insurance will cover that, fella." Smiling, she ripped the driver's side door off, and held the wreck up to her eye, getting a good look at the terrified man inside. Chantel laughed, making sure to show the man her blood-stained fangs. "Huh. For a black guy, you look awfully pale right now!" She tilted her head back and opened her mouth wide, dangling the truck cabin over her gaping jaw. "Well, time to meet the rest of your shithead friends!" she announces jovially, shaking the wrecked truck. The poor driver was knocked loose and fell screaming onto her tongue. Chantel resisted the urge to chew, enjoying his flavor for a moment before she closed her mouth and swallowed him whole, tracing his path down her throat with a finger.

"Damn, he's a real fighter--squirming up a storm," Chantel noted. She crushed the truck cabin in her hand and threw it at a larger building like a baseball. It smashed through the facade like an oversized bullet, and knocked through a support beam. The entire building imploded three seconds later, sending forth a cloud of dust and plaster in all directions. Chantel smiled so wide it hurt; she'd almost forgotten how fun this could be!

Flaring her wings out once more, Chantel pumped a fist into the air and let out her best roar. "I FUCKING LOVE THIS JOB!!" She exulted, and geared up to srpay fire into the air....

Until she felt bullets impact square on her behind.

Despite the ineffectiveness of the attack, Chantel actually yelped at the feeling of lead striking her backside.

Dragon or otherwise, getting shot in the ass was embarrassing as all hell.

Scowling with righteous indignation, she looked behind her, at the cluster of scrap-metal shacks. A small cluster of gunmen were running like merry hell out of them, firing sporadically into the air as they tried to flee the gargantuan dragon-girl that had descended on the town like a nightmare from hell.

But "nightmare from hell" was an inadequate title for Chantel at that moment. For now, she was not simply enjoying her mission, getting rid of some two-bit band of thugs. Now, she was a woman who had been embarrassed in front of her comrades. And as Shakespeare said, 'Hell hath no fury like a woman scorned!'

That was why Chantel decided that these jackasses deserved something special. A fate that went beyond what everyone else in this run-down excuse for a village had suffered. Besides, she'd secretly wanted to do this ever since she'd gotten huge.

Smiling devilishly, Chantel took quick steps back and to the side, keeping an eye on the fleeing gunmen. When she was sure her aim was right, she bent her knees and leaned back, laughing into the air as she sat down.

The fleeing men looked up just in time to see sixty metric tons worth of bikini-clad scaly Gluteus Maximus crash down onto them. It was actually a good view.

Chantel wriggled her rear, making sure the men were good and dead. Satisfied, she stood back up and nonchalantly stomped the last few buildings to rubble. She flapped her wings to extinguish the ring of fire that still encircled the town, and casually strolled back over to the camp over the ridge.

Needless to say, the soldiers had seen the while spectacle, and were appropriately gobsmacked. One of them produced a notepad and pen, and struggled to ask her for an autograph.

"Well boys, that's one town accounted for. You can move in!" She announced cheerfully.
